tn.text: This is the next event in the story. Possible setting: 1) this may have occurred on the same day that Jesus was questioned by the Sadducees ([[:en:bible:notes:luk:20:27|20:27]]) or 2) this may be a different day. Jesus begins teaching his disciples. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
"gifts of money"
"collection box" or "money box." This was one of the boxes in the temple courtyard where people put money as a gift to God.
This is a way of introducing a new character to the story. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]])

"two small coins" or "two tiny copper coins." These were the least valuable of the coins people used then. AT: "two pennies" or "two small coins of little value" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bmoney]])
This means that what Jesus was about to say was very important.
Jesus was talking to his disciples. The word "you" is plural. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

tn.ref: this poor widow put in more than all of them
tn.text: This does not mean she put in as much money as the rich men. Rather, it means that God considered her gift to be more significant that the larger sums the men gave. AT: "the small gift of this widow was more valuable than larger gifts of the rich men" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

tn.ref: gave gifts out of their abundance
tn.text: "have a lot of money but only gave a small portion of it"
"who has very little money"
Jesus switches from talking about the widow to teaching about the temple.
"things people had given to God"
This refers to the beautiful temple and its decorations.
"there will be a time when" or "someday"

tn.ref: not one stone will be left on another
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "enemies will not leave any stone on top of another" (See [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]]).

tn.ref: not one stone will be left ... not be torn down
tn.text: This can be stated in positive form. AT: "every stone will be removed from its place and they will all be torn down"

tn.ref: which will not be torn down
tn.text: This can be translated as a new sentence. AT: "They will all be torn down" or "Enemies will tear down every stone" (See [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"the disciples asked Jesus" or "Jesus' disciples asked him"
This refers to what Jesus just said about enemies destroying the temple.

Jesus was talking to his disciples. The word "you" is plural. AT: "that you do not believe lies" or "that no one deceives you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
People coming in his name claim to represent him. AT: "claiming to be me" or "claiming to have my authority" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"I am the Christ" or "I am the Messiah"
"Do not believe them" or "Do not become their disciples"
"do not let these things terrify you" or "do not be afraid"

tn.ref: the end will not happen immediately
tn.text: This refers to the final judgment. AT: "the end of the world will not happen immediately after the wars and riots" or "the world will not end immediately after those things happen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"the end of everything" or "the end of the age"
"Then Jesus said to his disciples." Since this is just a continuation of Jesus speaking from the previous verse, some languages may prefer not to say "Then he said to them."
"One nation will attack another nation." This can also be treated like a general statement. AT: "Nations will attack other nations"
This refers to ethnic groups of people rather than to countries.

Some words are not repeated to make this a short statement. AT: "kingdom will rise against kingdom" or "armies from one kingdom will attack armies from another kingdom" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: in various places famines and plagues
tn.text: Some words are not repeated to make this a short statement. AT: "there will be famines and plagues in many places" or "times of hunger and diseases that will kill many people in different places" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
"events that terrify people" or "events that cause people to be very afraid"
This refers to the terrible things that Jesus had said would happen.

tn.ref: they will lay their hands on you
tn.text: "they will grab you." This expression refers to people exercising authority over the disciples. AT: "they will arrest you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"people will" or "enemies will"
Jesus was talking to his disciples. The word "you" is plural. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

tn.ref: delivering you over to the synagogues
tn.text: "handing you over to the leaders of the synagogues." The leaders of the synagogues could forbid all the other Jews from interacting with the disciples because they follow Jesus.
"and delivering you over to the prisons" or "and putting you in prisons"
The word "name" is here used to refer to Jesus himself. AT: "because of me" or "because you follow me" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"for you to tell them your testimony about me"
"Because of this." Jesus uses this word here to refer back to everything he has said, beginning in [[:en:bible:notes:luk:21:10|21:10]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_connectingwords]])
The "heart" refers to the decisions of the whole person. AT: "make up your mind" or "decide firmly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"not to figure out what you will say in order to defend yourself against their accusations"

tn.ref: I will give you words and wisdom
tn.text: "I will tell you what wise things to say"
These can be combined into one phrase. AT: "words of wisdom" or "wise words" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hendiadys]])
This can be the start of a new sentence. AT: "All your adversaries"

tn.ref: which all your adversaries will not be able to resist or contradict
tn.text: It may be helpful to change the way the negative is used.  AT: "none of your adversaries will be able to argue against you or say that you are wrong"

tn.ref: you will be delivered up also by parents, brothers, relatives and friends
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "even your parents, brothers, relatives, and friends will hand you over to the authorities" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: they will put some of you to death
tn.text: "they will kill some of you." Possible meanings are 1) "the authorities will kill some of you" or 2) "those who deliver you up will kill some of you." The first meaning is more likely.

tn.ref: You will be hated by everyone
tn.text: This is an exaggeration to emphasize the seriousness of the persecution. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
"my name" here refers to Jesus. AT: "because of me" or "because you follow me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: But not a hair of your head will perish
tn.text: This refers to one of the smallest parts of a person to emphasize that the whole person will not perish. Jesus had already said that some of them would be put to death. So some understand this to mean that they would not be harmed spiritually. AT: "But these things cannot really harm you" or "Even every hair on your head will be safe" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"By holding firm." This can be stated in the opposite way. AT: "If you do not quit"
The "soul" was understood to represent the eternal part of a person. AT: "you will receive life" or "you will save yourselves" (UDB)
This can be stated in active form. AT: "armies surrounding Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"that it will soon be destroyed" or "that they will soon destroy it"
"run away from danger"
This refers to the rural areas outside Jerusalem, and not to the nation. AT: "outside the city"
"enter Jerusalem"
"these are days of punishment" or "this will be the time when God will punish this city" (UDB)

tn.ref: all the things that are written
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "all the things that the prophets wrote in the scriptures long ago" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "will happen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"to mothers who are nursing their babies"

tn.ref: there will be great distress upon the land
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) the people of the land will be distressed or 2) there will be physical disasters in the land.

"there will be wrath to the people at that time." God will bring this wrath. AT: "this people will experience God's anger" or "God will be very angry and will punish this people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: they will fall by the edge of the sword
tn.text: "they will be killed by the edge of the sword." AT: "the enemy soldiers will kill them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: they will be led captive into all the nations
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "their enemies will capture them and take them to other countries" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"into many other countries" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

tn.ref: Jerusalem will be trampled by the Gentiles
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) the Gentiles will conquer Jerusalem and occupy it or 2) the Gentiles will destroy the city of Jerusalem or 3) the Gentiles will destroy the people of Jerusalem. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

This metaphor speaks of Jerusalem as if the people of other nations was walking on it and crushing it down with their feet. This refers to domination. AT: "conquered by the Gentiles" or "destroyed by the other nations" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the times of the Gentiles are fulfilled
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "the period of the Gentiles has come to an end" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: there will be distress of the nations
tn.text: Here "the nations" refers to the people in them. AT: "the people of the nations will be distressed" or "the people of the nations will be very anxious"

tn.ref: in despair from the roar of the sea and waves
tn.text: "because they will be confused by the roar of the sea and its waves" or "and the loud noise of the sea and its rough movements will frighten the people." This seems to refer to unusual storms or disasters involving the seas.

tn.ref: the things which are coming upon the world
tn.text: "the things that will happen in the world" or "the things that will happen to the world"

tn.ref: the powers of the heavens will be shaken
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. Possible meanings are 1) the things in the sky like the sun, moon, and stars will not move in their normal way. AT: "God will shake the powerful things in the heavens" or 2) the powerful spirits in the heavens will be distressed. The first is recommended. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Jesus is refers to himself. AT: "me, the Son Man"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
"coming down in a cloud"

Here "power" probably refers to his authority to judge the world. Here "glory" may refer to a bright light. God sometimes shows his greatness with a very bright light. AT: "powerfully and gloriously" or "and he will be powerful and very glorious"
Sometimes when people are afraid, they crouch down in order to avoid being seen or hurt. When they are no longer afraid, they get up. AT: "stand up with confidence"
By lifting their heads to look up, they would be able to see their rescuer coming to them. AT: "look up" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom|Idiom]])

tn.ref: because your deliverance is coming near
tn.text: God, who delivers, is spoken of as if he were the deliverance that he causes. AT: "because your deliverer is coming to you" or "because God will soon save you"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
As Jesus continues teaching his disciples, he tells them a parable. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_parables]])
"When new leaves start to grow"

"summer is about to start." Summer in Israel follows the sprouting of fig tree leaves and is the time when the figs ripen. AT: "harvest time is ready to start" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: So also, when you see these things happening
tn.text: The appearance of the signs that Jesus just described signal the arrival of the kingdom of God just as appearance of the leaves of the fig tree signal the arrival of summer.

tn.ref: the kingdom of God is near
tn.text: "God will soon establish his kingdom." AT: "God will soon rule as king" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Jesus continues teaching his disciples.
This expression emphasizes the importance of what Jesus is about to say.
Possible meanings are 1) the generation that will see the first of the signs Jesus spoke of or 2) the generation Jesus was speaking to. The first is more likely.
This could be stated in positive form. AT: "will still be alive when"

tn.ref: Heaven and earth will pass away
tn.text: "Heaven and earth will cease to exist." The word "heaven" here refers to the sky and the universe beyond it.

tn.ref: my words will never pass away
tn.text: "my words will never cease to exist" or "my words will never fail." Jesus uses "words" here to refer to everything he says. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This could be stated in positive form. AT: "will remain forever"

tn.ref: so that your hearts are not burdened
tn.text: The "heart" here refers to the mind and thoughts of the person. AT: "so that you are not occupied with" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Jesus here speaks of the following sins as if they were a physical weight that a person had to carry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"drinking too much wine that would make one drunk"
"worrying too much about this life"

tn.ref: then that day will close on you suddenly like a trap
tn.text: Just as a trap closes on an animal when the animal does not expect it, that day will happen when people do not expect it. AT: "that day will happen when you are not expecting it, as when a trap closes suddenly on an animal" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: then that day will close on you suddenly
tn.text: The coming of that day will appear to be sudden and unexpected to those who are not ready and watching for it. AT: "For if you are not careful, that day will close on you suddenly."  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This refers to the day when the Messiah returns. AT: "the day when the Son of Man comes"
"it will affect everyone" or "the events of that day will affect everyone"

tn.ref: on the face of the whole earth
tn.text: The surface of the earth is spoken of as if it was the face of a person. That is, the outward part. AT: "on the surface of the whole earth" or "on the entire earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Jesus finishes teaching his disciples.
"be ready for my coming"

tn.ref: strong enough to escape all these things
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "strong enough to endure these things" or 2) "able to avoid these things."

tn.ref: these things that will take place
tn.text: "these things that will happen." Jesus had just told them about terrible things that would happen such as persecution, war, and captivity.

tn.ref: to stand before the Son of Man
tn.text: "to stand with confidence before the Son of Man." This probably refers to when the Son of Man judges everyone. A person who is not ready will be afraid of the Son of Man and will not stand with confidence.

This is the end of the part of the story that began in [[:en:bible:notes:luk:21:01|20:1]]. These verses tell on-going action that continues after the main part of the story ends. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_endofstory]])

tn.ref: during the days he was teaching
tn.text: "during the daytime he would teach" or "he would teach each day." The following verses tell about things that Jesus and the people did each day during the week before he died.
Only priests were allowed in the temple. AT: "at the temple" or "in the temple courtyard" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"at night he would go out of the city" or "he went out each night"
This is an exaggeration to emphasize the size of the crowd. AT: "A very large number of people" or "Almost everyone" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
"would come early each morning"
"to hear him teach"
